author: TylerLeonhardt
body:
<!--

For Windows PowerShell 5.1 issues, suggestions, or feature requests please use the following link instead:
Windows PowerShell [UserVoice](https://windowsserver.uservoice.com/forums/301869-powershell)

This repository is **ONLY** for PowerShell Core 6 and PowerShell 7+ issues.

- Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/known-issues-ps6?view=powershell-6).

-->

Lot's of folks depend on this behavior as it is what https://poshgui.com/Editor does by default. Tooling like this should "just work" in PS7.

# Steps to reproduce

```powershell
[System.Drawing.Font]'Microsoft Sans Serif,10'
```

# Expected behavior

```none
> [System.Drawing.Font]'Microsoft Sans Serif,10'   

FontFamily       : [FontFamily: Name=Microsoft Sans Serif] 
Bold             : False 
GdiCharSet       : 1 
GdiVerticalFont  : False
 Italic           : False 
Name             : Microsoft Sans Serif 
OriginalFontName : Microsoft Sans Serif 
Strikeout        : False
 Underline        : False 
Style            : Regular 
Size             : 10 
SizeInPoints     : 10 
Unit             : Point 
Height           : 16 
IsSystemFont     : False 
SystemFontName   :  
```

# Actual behavior

```none
InvalidArgument: Cannot convert the "Microsoft Sans Serif,10" value of type "System.String" to type "System.Drawing.Font".
```

# Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```none
 Name                           Value
 ----                           ----- 
PSVersion                      7.1.0-daily.20200421 
PSEdition                      Core 
GitCommitId                    7.1.0-daily.20200421
 OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.18363 
Platform                       Win32NT
 PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0â€¦} 
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
 SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1 
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

comments.author: SeeminglyScience
comments.body: Possible duplicate of or maybe fixed by #9863

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: I guess it is the same https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/35651

comments.author: safern
comments.body: This one is different. You need to explicitly have a reference to `System.Windows.Extensions` (the dll needs to be present at runtime), but that is only supported on Windows. This is somehow related to: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/1011 -- we're figuring out a plan to fix it as we where avoiding taking a dependency on System.ComponentModel.TypeConverters on System.Drawing.Common because of the size bloat it involves in apps.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
@safern Thanks! I tried your suggestion:
```
DEBUG: 2020-04-30 22:12:50.2491 TypeConversion Information: 0 : Custom type conversion.
DEBUG: 2020-04-30 22:12:50.2518 TypeConversion Information: 0 :     System.Drawing.Font's TypeConverterAttribute points to System.Drawing.FontConverter, System.Windows.Extensions, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=cc7b13ffcd2ddd51.
```
Version is wrong.

comments.author: safern
comments.body:
> Version is wrong.

Yep, you're right. We bumped the assembly versions and we didn't bump the TypeConverter reference. I think we should move out from the approach we have and instead take the dependency on ComponentModel. Will include this in the issue I linked above.

comments.author: safern
comments.body:
@iSazonov while what I mentioned above will fix the issue, I think you're hitting this because of the PS logic to load the typeconverters discussed here: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/35651#issuecomment-621994494

As if you use the `TypeConverter` logic to resolve the type, the loader even though the assembly version doesn't match, it will load it from the "latest" available assembly version so long it is greater than the specified assembly version, which in this case it should be fine.
